awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the relationship between civilian harm and the deliberate destruction of sites, monuments, and objects having group, religious, and artistic significance.  Theory and evidence are unclear on this issue.  In this project, time-space analytical techniques will be trained on a new dataset of incidents from a region in which both kinds of events occurred prominently at high rates.  The case is valuable for study because of the strong evidentiary base and because destructive incidents included many that existing theory would not have predicted.   Specifically, many incidents had neither apparent strategic advantage or ramifications for the civilian population.  Variations in technique, target, and timing will yield important insights into the intensity and location of civilian targeting and will assist scholars and decision makers to protect both humans and cultural sites and objects.

Newly available information from these events will be coded to support spatial and temporal analysis of two key categories of disruption: civilian harm and deliberate cultural destruction. Sociological theory has tended to view cultural destruction as an aspect of psychological hostile actions taken against a population.  This needs to be verified, however, by systematic analysis of the co-occurrence of the two kinds of disruption.  This project capitalizes on the dense and unusually detailed record of cultural destruction generated by official actors, less sanctioned groups, and civilian witnesses, including cell phone footage, films, print materials, and satellite images.   Data come from a three-year period (2014-2017) that saw a popular movement that fractured into multiple (often opposed) factions, interventions from the outside, intervention more locally, and overwhelming levels of the incidents in question. The resulting dataset will include georeferencing information in order to analyze the clustering of civilian harm before, during, and after cultural destruction events.  Analysis will proceed via appropriate statistical techniques including autoregressive distributed lag models (ARDL), clustering, vector autoregression (VAR), and event history analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Spatial-temporal analysis of social disintegration studied the relationship between civilian deaths and the destruction of cultural heritage during the Syrian war. Recent conflicts in several global regions have generated international interest in the plight of cultural objects and sites. These conflicts are diverse in their motives, participants, and goals, but cultural destruction is a common feature to all of them. At the same time, civilian deaths co-occur in many cases. Co-occurrence may indicate deliberate intention. It could also be a byproduct of diffuse destruction. Gaining a firmer understanding of the nature of how these types of violence co-occur was a primary goal of this project.

Scholars have generated a robust body of work on the destruction of historically sensitive sites and objects in conflict zones. This body of work can be divided into two primary themes: documenting the material loss that results from war, whether deliberate or inadvertent; and analyzing the effects of this loss on local communities. A common argument across these studies is that attacks on culture weaken the identity of target populations. But these and other studies leave an important gap: they do not clarify what the relationship is between culture and civilian deaths. This is an empirical question. It is what we set out to address with a new data set and new methods. It forms the backbone of our significant results. The Syrian war presented a unique opportunity to do this work because of the tragic features of the conflict, as captured through multi-level observations over a sustained period.

To address the gaps in our knowledge, the project had two major goals. (1) The first was to create a fully georeferenced database of cultural damage events in Syria that could support a range of quantitative studies of violence patterns, including possible models to predict the stability of future postwar community rebuilding efforts. (2) The second was to conduct micro level study of violence dynamics, focusing on the possible co-location of cultural damage and civilian fatalities. Both goals were achieved. Other major goals were to contribute to theories of cultural violence and of genocide; to contribute to scholarly and practitioner work on community disintegration and rebuilding; and to create a new data environment for our own research questions and other scholars' related questions.

Our project capitalized on the dense and unusually detailed record of cultural destruction generated during the war in Syria. We analyzed social media, eyewitness reports, government reports, and satellite images.  We chose to focus on a three-year period (2014-2017) that saw a popular insurgency that fractured into multiple (often opposed) armed factions, military strikes by foreign governments, repressive state intervention, and overwhelming levels of targeted physical and symbolic violence. Multiple actor groups, coexisting in shifting alliances and with great variation in time and space, required us to design exquisitely sensitive metadata decisions for the coding work.

Major activities were data creation, statistical model testing, and analysis. The grant included support for a collaboration with the Uppsala Conflict Data Program (UCDP). The UCDP tracks organized violence and civil war around the world, using open sources of information that are systematically triangulated and verified. They georeferenced the cultural destruction events in our database. One result of this collaboration is a novel dataset that brings together civilian deaths and cultural heritage violence into the same analytical framework. The dataset includes georeferencing information to support a range of analytical techniques for measuring how civilian casualties cluster before, during, and after cultural destruction events. It is available from the PI by request.

In addition to the outcomes described above, we published academic papers; generated mid-point public presentations of our work; trained graduate researchers in data coding and analysis; created an international collaboration; and established a novel methodology using spatial statistics to study cultural violence.
